The paper describes the catalytic epoxidation of methyl esters of higher fatty acids prepared from waste vegetable oils as a renewable raw material (the second important product is glycerol). Bio-epoxides as "green products" can be used instead of epoxides from crude oil in many applications such as bio-lubricants, biopolymers, polycarbonates, etc. The epoxidation was catalysed by γ-alumina impregnated with tungsten (5–15 wt.%) under different reaction conditions such as the type and amount of solvent (acetonitrile, ethyl acetate and tert‑butanol) and amount of catalysts (0 to 75 wt.% to ester), molar ratio to ester (from 1 to 6) and reaction time (0–24 h). Characterization of tested catalysts was carried out by various analytical methods such as XRF, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TPD-NH3, N2 physisorption, Hg-porozimetry, SEM-EDX. Moreover, the ternary plot for each solvent was determined to find the homogeneous region since ester and hydrogen peroxide are immiscible liquids. Finally, according to statistical evaluationed, it was found that methyl ester conversion increases with increasing number of WO bonds. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methyl ester Epoxidation WO3/Al2O3 catalyst Biolubricants Ternary plots Data availability Data will be made available on request. Nomenclature and abbreviations ACN acetonitrile AMT ammonium metatungstate hydrate ME methyl ester PCA principal component analysis SEM-EDX scanning electron microscope – Energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy SIMDIS simulated distillation TPD temperature programmed desorption XRF X-ray fluorescence analysis XRD X-ray diffraction S BET specific surface area (m2/g) 1 Introduction Lubricating oils are essential for the proper functioning of almost all of the mechanical machinery in the world. The most common base component is mineral oil, which is composed from hydrocarbons derived from the heavy fractions produced during petroleum refining [1]. However, petroleum-based lubricating oils can contaminate soil and air and thus be hazardous to plants, animals, and human health [2]. Concerns about the depletion of oil reserves and increasing environmental protection have led to the search for "green products" as a more environmentally sustainable alternative [3,4,5]. A promising solution could be the use of lubricants based on vegetable oils [2,6], which have advantages, such as high lubricity, viscosity index, flash point, and low evaporative losses [7]. On the other hand, vegetable oils have several disadvantages, such as (i) poor oxidative and thermal stability due to the presence of unsaturated substances [8,9], (ii) the low-temperature fluidity [10] and (iii) poor corrosion protection. It is therefore not possible to use vegetable oils directly as lubricants. For application as biolubricants, the most important is oxidation stability, which is increasing by epoxidation [11]. Instead of bio-lubricants, the epoxides can be applied as additives to various synthetic components of paints, coatings, surface treatments. In addition, the highly reactive nature of the oxirane group allows their use as starting materials for (i) biopolymers (as monomers), (ii) the formation of higher alcohols, olefins, glycols, polyesters and carbonates. However, the use of edible vegetable oils to produce biocomponents is problematic due to competition with food crops. It is better to apply used cooking oils [12], whose production in the EU exceeds over 700,000 tonnes per year [13] and would contribute to maximizing recycling and reuse of waste [12]. Another possibility is nonedible-oil, which cannot be used for biodiesel due to high iodine value. Moreover, glycerol is formed during production of methyl esters by transesterification, which is important for industry and its consumption is constantly increasing [14]. The disadvantage is the price, which is currently higher than that of crude oil. Therefore, the first step is transesterification, i.e. reaction of triacylglycerides with methanol formed mixture of esters (used for epoxidation) and glycerol [15]. The second step is an epoxidation, which is the conversion of the double bonds between two carbons into an oxirane ring. The most common epoxidation is the Prilezhaev reaction in the presence of performic or peracetic acid and “homogeneous” catalyst (mineral acid), Fig. 1 [16]. However, the use of acids can result in undesirable side reactions forming by-products such as diols, hydroxyl esters, estolides and other dimers, which can cause low epoxy content in the final product [13]. The acids cause equipment corrosion and have to be neutralized and removed after reaction [17,11], increasing the environmental impact. The solution of mentioned disadvantages of the homogeneous catalyst can be overcome by use of the heterogeneous catalysts. Moreover, the absence of acids in the reaction mixture leads to (i) fewer side reactions and (ii) easy separation of final products (without neutralisation of acids). On the other hand, the raw materials (non-polar esters and polar hydrogen peroxide) are immiscible liquids and together with the solid catalyst form three phases in the reaction mixture. Solvents such as acetonitrile, ethyl acetate [18], tert‑butanol [19], methanol and diisopropylether are added to decrease amount of phases [20], because of eliminating of mass transfer and consequently accelerating the interaction of the reactants with the heterogeneous catalysts [21]. The heterogeneous catalysts containing transition metals in their highest oxidation states (Mo(VI), Ti(IV) and W(VI)) represent an important class of compounds mainly due to their oxygen transfer activity [22-24]. However, the leaching in presence of hydrogen peroxide was published for molybdenum species [25]. The special type of titanium – tetravalent species as TS-1 (Titanium silicate), which it is quite difficult to synthesise in the sable form, are only active in the epoxidation. Moreover, TS-1 is microporous materials derived from zeolite and the pores can be blocked by methyl esters (larger molecule than pores) [26].The metals are often applied on support γ- and α-Al2O3 [27,28], due to its Brønsted and Lewis acid-base properties, high surface area and good porosity [29], allowing high dispersion of the metal catalyst [30]. As a powder, it can be formed shaped and has excellent mechanical strength and hydrothermal and chemical stability [31]. Tungsten supported on alumina was chosen as because it is relatively to synthesise and contains mesopores [32]. The aim of this work is to find the optimal catalyst composition (WO3/Al2O3) and reaction conditions for the epoxidation of mixture of methyl esters (biodiesel), which is different from other papers (pure methyl oleate is often used). The novelty is also the determination of ternary plots for solvents to find the homogeneous region. The catalysts were deeply characterized by many methods such as X-ray fluorescence analysis and X-ray diffraction, N2 physisorption, Hg porosimetry, etc. Outcomes were statistically evaluated to find the relation between catalyst properties and epoxidation results. Therefore, without use of homogenous acids, all products will be environmentally friendly. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Synthesis of WO3/Al2O3 catalysts The catalysts were prepared by incipient wet impregnation of ammonium metatungstate hydrate (AMT) (99.9%wt., Sigma Aldrich) on commercial support γ‐Al2O3 spheres. The support (Sasol, 2.5 mm diameter) was crushed and sieved to obtain fraction 224–560 µm (Retsch AS 300). The target content of tungsten was 5.0, 7.5, 10.0, 12.5 and 15.0 wt% (the solutions 0.73, 1.13, 1.56, 2.02 and 2.52 g of AMT in 20 g of water were prepared and stirred with 10 g of Al2O3). Subsequently, the obtained materials were dried in air at 120 °C for 6 h and then calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h (heating rate of 1 °C/min). 2.2 Characterisation of catalysts X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF) was used to determine the elemental composition of catalysts. The samples were measured on an S8 Tiger (Bruker AXS GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany) with Rh cathode and the quant-express method (without a standard) was used. The results were evaluated using Spectra plus software (Version 3). The crystallographic structure of the catalysts was determined using the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. Analysis was performed using the D8 Advance ECO (Bruker AXC GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany) with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) and with the step size of 0.02° and a step time of 0.5 s. The XRD patterns were collected in the range from 5° to 70° 2theta and evaluated using the Diffrac.Eva software (Bruker AXS GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany) and the Powder Diffraction File database (PDF 4 + 2018, International Centre for Diffraction Data, Newtown Square, PA, USA). The Raman spectroscopy (DXR instrument, Thermo Fischer Scientific, Waltham, Mass., USA) was used for the identification of W–O bonds and was performed equipped by 532 nm laser. The deconvolution was performed using a Gaussian curve in Origin 9.1 while respecting the positions of the individual bands [33]. The acidity was determined by temperature programmed desorption (TPD-NH3), which was performed on an AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with an OmniStarTM GSD 320 (Pfeiffer Vacuum, Germany) mass spectrometer. The material (100 mg) was placed in a quartz reactor and heated to 550 °C in a flow of helium (25 ml/min, rate of 10 °C/min and purity 99.999 %). Then, the sample was cooled to 70 °C at the same flow rates and maintaining the temperature for 15 min and adsorption of ammonium from the atmosphere of mixture He with NH3. The desorption was carried out from 70 to 550 °C in inert He atmosphere (25 ml/min). The accuracy of the method is approximately ± 5 rel.%. Specific surface area, pore size distribution, and pore volume were calculated from the 69-point adsorption/desorption isotherm by N2 physisorption at 77 K using an Autosorb iQ-XR-XR (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL, USA). Before the analysis, all samples were dried under vacuum for 24 h at 110 °C in a glass cell to remove unwanted vapours. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used for the calculation of the surface area in the linear range of 0.05–0.30 p/p₀. The total pore volume was obtained from the isotherm at 0.995 p/p₀. The mesopore size distribution was evaluated by Non-Local Density Functional Theory using adsorption branch kernel on silica based on a cylindrical pore model. The distribution of macropores, mesopores and total intrusion volume were obtained by mercury porosimetry performed on an AutoPore IV 9510 (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation, Norcross, GA, USA). Before measuring the intrusion/extrusion curve, the prepared samples were degassed at 110 °C for 16 h under vacuum. After drying, each prepared sample was loaded into a 3 mL-solid penetrometer with a total stem volume of 0.412 mL. First, the penetrometer was inserted into the low-pressure port, where analysis was performed in the range of 0–345 kPa. Then, the penetrometer was inserted into the high-pressure port and analysis was performed up to 413 MPa. The result of the measurement was the intrusion curve (dependence of intrusion volume (mL) on pressure (MPa)/pore diameter (nm)). Scanning electron microscope with Energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) JSM-IT500HR (JEOL Ltd., Akishima, Tokyo Prefecture, Japan) were used for SEM figures and the chemical composition of the surface and mapping. Note: the analysis was performed for four random catalyst sites due to elimination of determination error. 2.3 Ternary plots The ternary plots were determined by measuring of the transmittance via spectrophotometric method at a wavelength of 450 nm and at temperature of 50 °C, which is the same as the reaction temperature. The methyl esters (ME) were considered as a single chemical substance (differences between each ester are insignificant for miscibility) and its transmittance was 100%. The non-miscible esters and hydrogen peroxide were stirred together, which formed a heterogeneous system with low transmittance. Then, one solvent (acetonitrile, ethyl acetate and tert‑butanol) was added, and the transmittance was monitored. When the transmittance rapidly increased, the system became homogeneous, which indicated one point of the binodal curve of the ternary plot. The final plot was elaborated in the program Origin 9.1. 2.4 Epoxidation of methyl esters The methyl esters were used as raw materials for epoxidation and prepared from waste vegetable oil at standard procedure [34]. The density (0.88 g/cm3), kinematic viscosity (4.5 mm2/s), water content (450 ppm), the acid number (0.06 mg KOH/g) and the number of double bonds (106.2 g I2/g) of ME were determined. The epoxidation was carried out by hydrogen peroxide (30 wt.%) in 250 ml double-necked glass flask with a reflux condenser at 50 °C and a stirring speed of 400 rpm for 24 h. The amount of ME was always 1.5 g and After reaction, the catalyst was separated from the product by filtration. The reaction conditions are based on preliminary experiments and paper [20]. The effects of the (i) type and amount of solvent, (ii) hydrogen peroxide, (iii) amount of catalyst and (iv) tungsten content in the catalyst were studied (Table 1 ). The methyl esters (ME) conversion was determined on an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph with an FID detector and Rtx-5MS capillary column (30 m; 0.25 mm ID; 0.25 µm). The methyl esters without oxirane rings were identified by standards and the conversion (XME ) was calculated according to equation (1) (1) X M E = m M E b e f o r e r e a c t i o n − m M E a f t e r r e a c t i o n m M E b e f o r e r e a c t i o n · 100 where mME is the amount of esters before and after reaction determined from calibration curve (pure ester was applied as standard). The products of epoxidation (esters with oxirane ring and possible products of hydrolysis or oxidative cleavage) were determined by simulated distillation (SIMDIS) on an Agilent 7890 gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, Calif., USA) with an MXT-1HT SI Dis capillary column (5 m; 53 mm; 0.1 µm). The results were statistically evaluated by software Statistica 12 (USA) to construct a principal component analysis plot (PCA), which reveals hidden relations between the properties of epoxides. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation of W/Al2O3 catalysts X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis was performed to verify the actual concentration of tungsten and aluminium (Table 2 ). The content of some other metals (Ce, S, Fe) was <0.1 wt.%. The concentrations determined are close to the theoretical ones with a difference approximately ±0.5 wt.%. The tungsten is in the form of oxide tungsten trioxide (see section XRD and Raman spectroscopy) and the Al/O molar ratio decrease since higher tungsten content means higher oxygen. The catalysts are denoted according to theoretical content of tungsten such as 5% W/Al2O3. The structure of the W/Al2O3 catalysts was studied by X-ray diffraction analysis (Fig. 2 ). Firstly, the amount of the crystallinity was determined in the interval 45–52 %, indicating relatively low crystallinity and thus good dispersion of the tungsten in the catalysts structure. The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 37.3°, 45.9° and 67.0° (indexed to (111), (200) and (220) plane of γ-Al2O3, respectively). The tungsten is probably present in the form of trioxide, which is the most stable tungstate oxide after calcination in the air [35]. The reflection for WO3 (especially stable orthorhombic structure), was slightly observed only for the catalyst with the highest tungsten content (23.6°). The other diffraction lines (2 θ of 23.1, 24.2 and 34.1° [36]) were not observed most probably due to an amorphous nature or high dispersion of WO3 on Al2O3 support [37]. These results are in accordance with R. Moraes et al., who also determined lines for WO3 only for higher amount of tungsten [38]. The Raman spectroscopy was used to identify type of bonds between tungsten and oxygen (Fig. 3 ), which influence the epoxidation. The small band with a Raman shift at 798 cm-1 was attributed to the WO stretching mode of WO3 and was presented only for the highest content of tungsten, which corresponds with the XRD (the reflection for WO3 was also found). Note: The most intensive band for WO3 is with maximum around 800 cm-1 and others are less intensive with shift at 700 and 256 cm-1 [39] or 717 and 272 cm-1 [40]. The maximum has also been published at 829, 690 and 256 cm-1 [41]. The exact Raman shift depends on the type of WO3 such as (nano)particles or thin-layer, the method of preparation, purity, and water content. The highest band from 970 to 1000 cm-1 is assigned to symmetric stretching vibrations of terminal WO bonds in octedral polytungstain. The bands (1060, 387 and 372 cm-1) attributed to Al2(WO4)3 were not identified, but a distorted WO4 structure with the intensive bands 970–990 cm-1 was identified [33]. To determine the presence of individual bond, the area of bands attributed to various tungsten – oxygen: bonds was deconvoluted: single bond W–O–W at maximum around 970 cm-1 and double bond WO at maximums of 870, 880, 927 cm-1 (Fig. 3A) [33]. The dependence of the double to single bond area ratio increases with increasing tungsten content (Fig. 3B). The acid properties (amount of acid sites) were determined using TPD-NH3 (Fig. 4 ). Alumina itself is an acid material and the total acidity slightly increase with increasing tungsten content (Table 3 ). Similar desorption profile with one maximum at 185 °C was observed for all catalysts and it does not therefore dependent on the amount of tungsten. For lower tungsten content, a slightly higher amount of strong acid sites was observed (temperatures 250–500 °C) than for higher tungsten content (Fig. 4B). The TPD profiles are the same for higher tungsten content above 10 wt.%. Therefore, higher tungsten amount increases the total acidity, but decrease the strong acid sites. The adsorption/desorption N2 isotherms for all W/Al2O3 were determined and pore diameter calculated (Fig. 5 ). All catalysts showed type IV isotherm with hysteresis loop type H2 regardless the tungsten amount (according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) [42]). The isotherm is typical for mesoporous materials and the hysteresis loop H2 is often associated with narrow necks, wide bodies (inkbottle-shaped pores) and pore blocking/percolation [43,44]. The pore size distribution (Fig. 5B), pore volume and mesopore volume and the surface area (S BET) were calculated from isotherms. It was found that all catalysts had one peak on the distribution curve with pore diameter ranging from 6 to 14 nm and maximum of 9.4 nm. The pore and mesopore volume decreased with increasing tungsten concentration from a value of 0.483 cm3/g to 0.411 cm³/g (Table 3), which corresponded with the slight decrease of S BET (from 184 to 171 m2/g). The reason for this is the slight filing of the pores by the tungsten, resulting in a slight decrease in surface area. Wonjin et al., published the S BET in the similar range for the same support, but different transition metals [45]. Therefore, the type of isotherm, hysteresis loop and thus pore size distribution is almost independent on the content of tungsten, indicating that the tungsten is homogeneously dispersed. Hg porosimetry was used to determine the intrusion curve and the pore size distribution of meso‑ and macropores (Fig. 6 ). The catalyst contained mainly pores with the size of 8.1 nm in agreement with the N2 physisorption (pore diameter with maximum of 9.4 nm was determined, Fig. 5a). The second peak was observed with the maximum of about 14 µm, which indicates the presence of macropores. The total intrusion and mesopore volumes in the range of 3–50 nm were further determined (Table 3) and both decreased with increasing tungsten content, which corresponded with the trend observed for N2 physisorption. All catalysts were analysed by SEM-EDX (Figs. S1 and S2 in N material). The SEM images show the macropores with similar size, which is in accordance with pore size distribution with one maximum around 14 µm determined by Hg-porosimetry (Fig. 6a). The EDX analysis shows a high degree of tungsten distribution on the support for all catalysts, i.e. tungsten is homogeneously distributed (similar results was published [46]). Furthermore, the distribution of aluminium and oxygen (catalyst support) was also homogeneous. The bright luminous formations, which are typical of tungsten clusters [47] were not observed, so clusters were not presented. The clusters have a negative effect on the activity of the catalyst because some active sites would be overlapped by others (the amount of active sites is reduced) and so not accessible for raw materials. The homogeneous distribution of tungsten corresponded with the outcomes from XRD, where only one unremarkable line was found for WO3 at higher amount of tungsten. 3.2 Epoxidation of methyl ester 3.2.1 Type of solvent The raw materials for epoxidation (non-polar esters and polar hydrogen peroxide) are immiscible liquids and together with the solid catalyst formed three phases in the reaction mixture. To reduce the influence of transport phenomena [21], the number of phases was decreased by addition of polar solvent (acetonitrile – ACN, ethyl acetate and tert‑butanol) to one liquid and one solid. These solvents have higher boiling point than reaction temperature 50 °C. The ternary plots for mixture of each solvent with esters and hydrogen peroxide were determined at 50 °C to find the homogeneous region (Fig. 7 ). Note: the methyl esters were considered as a single chemical substance. The application of methyl esters (mixture of many types of esters) from real waste oil is differs from many other papers, where only methyl oleate was used. The ternary plots for acetonitrile and ethyl acetate are similar with very small homogeneous region, i.e., quite large amount of solvent is necessary to add to the make reaction mixture homogeneous. The most homogeneous region was obtained for tert‑butanol because it contains -OH group as well as water and hydrogen peroxide, which caused better miscibility than acetonitrile and ethyl acetate. Note: the ternary plots are valid for methyl esters regardless the origin of vegetable oil from which are prepared (i.e., iodine value), because it does not influence the miscibility. Each solvent was tested with two esters present in the reaction mixture (2.2 and 4.1 wt.%) so that the reaction mixture was homogeneous, which was determined from ternary plots (Fig. 7A– red points). The other reaction conditions (based on preliminary experiments) were the same: 2.5 g catalyst 12.5% W/Al2O3, reaction temperature 50 °C, the molar ratio of H2O2 to double bonds 3.5. The ME conversion decreased with increasing electric dipole moment of solvent (Fig. 8A ), the highest conversion was achieved for acetonitrile (11.50·10–30C.m), lower conversion for ethyl acetate (6.27·10–30C.m) and tert‑butanol (4.37·10–30C.m). These results are regardless to amounts of solvents and the reason is that protic solvents had a negative effect on the conversion. On the other hand, N. Wilde at al. find that the conversion is slightly better using ethyl acetate than acetonitrile, but for a different catalyst (Titanium Silicalite-1) and pure methyl oleate as raw material [20]. The highest ME conversion (almost 80 %) was obtained with ACN and therefore it was chosen for further epoxidation. The different amounts of esters in the reaction mixture (from 1 to 8.1 wt.%) for ACN were tested (Fig. 8B). The increase of esters content (less solvent) causes the decrease of esters conversion from 86 to 56%, because the reaction mixture was heterogenous for higher amounts of esters (higher than 4.6 wt% is in heterogeneous region). Therefore, the esters content 4.1 wt% was applied for further measurements (weight ratio of ME to ACN was 0.05). 3.2.2 Effect of amount of hydrogen peroxide and catalyst Hydrogen peroxide, as a starting substance, has a major influence on the epoxidation process [48]. The dependence of esters conversion on the molar ratio of H2O2 to double bonds (H₂O₂/CC) was determined (Fig. 9A ). It was found that the conversion increased with an increasing H2O2/CC molar ratio of to three, because the equilibrium is shifted to the products, which was expected. At higher values of the molar ratio, there is a slight decrease in conversion because mass transfer into the solid catalyst is limited. Therefore, a molar ratio of H2O2/CC of two was chosen for further testing. The amount of catalyst plays key role in the epoxidation process [49] and was tested from 0 to 75 wt.% of catalyst to esters (Fig. 9B). The ester conversion was 0% without a catalyst, i.e., catalyst is required for epoxidation. It was found that the ester conversion increased rapidly (from 21 to 68%) with an increasing amount of catalyst up to 45 wt.% and then remained almost constant. Therefore, this amount was chosen for further testing. 3.2.3 Effect of tungsten amount in the catalyst The optimal reaction conditions (4.4 wt.% of ester in acetonitrile as solvent, molar ratio of H2O2/CC of two and 45 wt.% of catalyst to ester) were applied for determination of ME conversion on time (24 h) for different amount of tungsten (5–15 wt.%), Fig. 10 . The ME conversion increased with increasing tungsten, reaching 80 % after 24 h for the 15% W/Al2O3. However, the epoxides can undergo other subsequent reactions such as hydrolysis to diols or oxidative cleavage, which formation was suggested in reaction scheme [20]. The small amount of nonanal and methyl-9-oxononanoate were determined in the reaction mixture. The selectivity of nonanal was only 0.5 % at 60 % ME conversion but increased with increasing conversion (1.5 % at 80 % ME conversion), Fig 10b. These products are formed by the oxidative cleavage of methyl-9,10-epoxystearate, which is formed by epoxidation of methyl oleate (the main component of the esters) [50-52]. After 24 h, the reaction mixture was analysed by simulated distillation (Fig. 11 ). Several signals were determined and identified according to pure methyl ester (without oxirane ring) and paper [53]: (i) small peak at 330 °C and higher peak at 350 °C belonged to all ME without oxirane ring with 16 and 18 carbons, (ii) the peak with temperature 375 °C belong to the epoxides and (iii) the peak with the boiling point higher than 395 °C corresponds to polyols formed by hydrolysis of epoxides (oxygen increases the boiling point). For 12.5 and 15% W/Al2O3, the peaks ME without oxirane ring, which belong to saturated ME and cannot be epoxides, are presented. Slight amount of polyols was observed only for 15% W/Al2O3, where the highest conversion was determined, which is in correspondence with paper [53]. 3.3 Evaluation of results In addition, all results were statistically evaluated by PCA and two formed groups contain 99 % of all information (Fig. 12 ). One group (left side) with a positive correlation between tungsten content, acidity, ME conversion and selectivity to nonanal (after 24 h) was found. The increased tungsten content caused more active sites (WO) and so acidity (desorbed NH3), which increased ME conversion, but also caused subsequent reactions (nonanal formation). The second group (right side) with positive correlation includes all textural properties determined by N2 isotherms and Hg porosimetry, but the variability of textural properties is not high (Table 3) and so the dependency not very significant. There is a negative correlation between these two groups. Overall, increasing tungsten results in higher ME conversion and so higher oxirane amount (Fig. 10A), but slightly decreases the specific surface area and all pore volumes, because tungsten fills the pores of support and also causes relatively lower γ-alumina content. Note: The conversion is not the same as selectivity, because small amount of by-produces were formed by (i) the oxidative cleavage of epoxides or (ii) polymerization to formed of polyols (by hydrolysis of epoxides). The epoxidation results are quite difficult to compare with other papers, because the heterogeneous catalyst with different types and amounts of metals (Ti, W, Cu, Mn, …) and way of synthesis methods were used. The reaction conditions are also very different, such as (i) type of reactor (batch or flow), (ii) presence of cosolvent, (iii) the type and amount of cosolvent, (iv) the ratio of hydrogen peroxide and catalyst to esters, (v) the reaction temperature (20–80 °C) and time (2–24 h). W. Jeon et al. published the dependency of conversion of methyl oleate on the type and content of transition metal supported on Al2O3 in wide range from 3.8 to 48 wt.% (depends on the type of metals) [45]. Other authors published various Ti-containing silica catalysts for epoxidation of methyl oleate and methyl esters, which exhibited the conversion of unsaturated methyl esters from 42 to 94% after 24 h for catalyst. M. Guidotti et al. published conversion from 4.5 to 75 % for catalyst Ti(IV)-grafted silica for different molar ratios SiO2 to TiO2 [54]. For other catalyst containing titanium on different type of support, the conversion of methyl oleate was from 2 to 90% and depends on the reaction conditions such as type of support, type of cosolvent and temperature [20]. Therefore, the conversion almost 80 % in this study is in the higher range of published conversions. 4 Conclusion The epoxidation of methyl esters (biodiesel) on the heterogeneous catalysts W/Al2O3 was carried out under different reaction conditions. The use of heterogeneous catalysts is more environmentally friendly because no acids are used as in the case of homogeneous catalysts. The ternary plots for three solvents were determined to find the miscibility region due to decreasing of phases amount in the reaction mixture. According to the statistical evaluation of all outcomes it was found that increasing amount of tungsten causes (i) increase of the acid sites, which results in greater conversion of methyl ester, (ii) decreasing of textural properties such as specific surface area and pore volumes. On the other hand, the oxidative cleavage of epoxides also increased with increasing tungsten content. The highest conversion was at the following reaction conditions: acetonitrile as the solvent, the content of ester in reaction mixture 4.1 wt.%, molar ratio H2O2/CC of two and 30 wt% of catalyst. The formed bio-epoxides can be applied directly as bio-lubricants or as raw materials for other components, such as bio-polymers, carbonates, dyes, rubber, polyesters etc. The bio-epoxides in these applications can partially replace the crude oil and will contribute to the decarbonisation of the industry. coredata.dc:description: The paper describes the catalytic epoxidation of methyl esters of higher fatty acids prepared from waste vegetable oils as a renewable raw material (the second important product is glycerol). Bio-epoxides as "green products" can be used instead of epoxides from crude oil in many applications such as bio-lubricants, biopolymers, polycarbonates, etc. The epoxidation was catalysed by γ-alumina impregnated with tungsten (5–15 wt.%) under different reaction conditions such as the type and amount of solvent (acetonitrile, ethyl acetate and tert‑butanol) and amount of catalysts (0 to 75 wt.% to ester), molar ratio to ester (from 1 to 6) and reaction time (0–24 h). Characterization of tested catalysts was carried out by various analytical methods such as XRF, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TPD-NH3, N2 physisorption, Hg-porozimetry, SEM-EDX. Moreover, the ternary plot for each solvent was determined to find the homogeneous region since ester and hydrogen peroxide are immiscible liquids. Finally, according to statistical evaluationed, it was found that methyl ester conversion increases with increasing number of WO bonds.
